Mike Clark wrote:
>>One of the concerns that I (and
>>developers) have is that we will end up with thousands of test cases, 
>>many
>>of which will involve using substantial amounts of MockObjects to set 
>>up
>>test cases and that all this will become too much of an overhead to 
>>manage &
>>maintain.
> 
> Substantial amounts of MockObjects raises a red flag for me.  It means 
> that there may be areas where an object needing to be mocked has taken 
> too much control in the system.  I can't speak to your system of 
> course, but here's something I see regularly:

If you mean lots of mocks with complicated set up, then I agree there's 
a problem, but there are other ways to look at it.

> Say we have a method that takes a BigObject and does something with a 
> subset of the data in that object:
> 
>     public void doSomething(BigObject o) {
>        String s = o.getStringValue();
>        int i = o.getIntValue();
>        // do something with 's' and 'i'
>     }
> 
> There are several other methods like doSomething() in the system, so 
> the initial reaction is to mock BigObject so that we can pass it into 
> doSomething() and the other methods.  BigObject has a lot of setup 
> involved to put it into a test state, but with some effort we can 
> create a MockBigObject.

The problem here is not the mocking of BigObject, but the complex setup 
that requires, because it's doing too much work or is too tightly 
coupled, or something. What if BigObject were an interface which would 
make mocking up trivial?

> But the doSomething() method is really trying to tell us that it 
> doesn't want a BigObject.  It just wants a String and an int:
> 
>     public void doSomething(String s, int i) {
>        // do something with 's' and 'i'
>     }
> 
> OK, now we only have to initialize a String and an int to pass into 
> doSomething() during the test.  Can we do the same thing with other 
> methods that take a BigObject?  Or do those methods share the need for 
> a subset of data we can package in a SmallerObject?

Extracting subtypes is exactly the right thing to do, normally I'd 
prefer to do this with an interface. I have doubts about unpacking 
individual fields because that's a loss of information. The type system 
no longer tells us about the relationships between whatever the string 
and int represent, and I find myself increasingly distrusting the use of 
basic types in Java.

Again, once you have an interface, mocking becomes trivial.

> I would suggest mocking as a last resort as often times it's a band-aid 
 > for what the system really wants. I find that if I reach for mocking
 > first, then I miss those design opportunities.

That makes sense to me only if you're talking about mocking unpleasant 
existing featuers. On the other hand, struggling to do so often 
highlights the dependencies you need to untangle.

S
